content.text: How To Add New Custom Lint Rules

inlineContent.text: In order to add a new lint rule, the following steps must be adhered to:
Create a new shell script file in the customLintScripts directory.
Declare a
variable containing the regular expression you wish to lint against. E.g.
Declare the following
variable below:
Declare a
variable to contain the error message you wish to throw if the regular expression matches. E.g.

inlineContent.code: MESSAGE="There should be no hardcoded hex values. Please use \Ribbons.color instead."

inlineContent.text: Include the following final line of code at the bottom of your file, which searches through the project directory (excluding test directories), and attempts to match the regular expression against the contents of each of the files found:
The resulting file would then look as follows:

code: MESSAGE="There should be no hardcoded hex values. Please use \`Ribbons.color\` instead."

inlineContent.text: Build Phase Run Script
Please ensure that the following build phase run script is included:

code: for f in "${SRCROOT}/BuildPhaseScripts/CustomLintScripts/"*.sh; do bash "$f" -H; done

inlineContent.text: If the above is not included, custom linting will not take place.

Grids are design structures with a deep history. Early print designers utilised grids to organise text blocks and images into pleasing visual hierarchies that aided readability. As design has evolved but the same basic principles still apply to the two-dimensional organization of information.

The snapshots were generated for 4 different sets:
iPhone 8 with iOS 14.5
iPhone 13 with iOS 15
iPad Air 3rd Generation with iOS 14.5
iPad Air 3rd Generation with iOS 15.0
There are some technical reasons for this:
The reason to use iOS 15 and iOS 14.5 is because for example, the tab bar, has a slightly different shadow/border in iOS 14, but not in iOS 15. Apart from that, there are some small
among different OS versions.
The reason to use iPad and iPhone is because some styles/labels, change the sizes of fonts depending on the idiom (iPhone or iPad).
You can see the API reference in the next sections.
If you are using Xcode/Developer Documentation to read this documentation, you can also use the left column, or navigator.
Note that this option is not available when using the online version.
